Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: A Roadside Marijuana Breathalyzer to Rapidly Screen for Cannabinoid Sobriety
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will be an affordable, portable breath analysis device to detect marijuana intoxication. First responders, law enforcement, medical professionals, cannabis users, and the general public will benefit from an analytical tool that allows fast and accurate screenings of cannabis impairment. An estimated 37,000 people died in vehicle crashes in 2016; 54% of the victims were tested for drugs and alcohol, and 38% of those tested positive for marijuana. The proposed device will enable objective determination of cannabis impairment, improving road safety.<br/><br/>The proposed project is based on engineering detectable, reproducible interactions between an array of biomimetic polymer coatings trained to detect gas-phase molecular components that are markers of cannabis intoxication. Drawing inspiration from the principles and chemical features of nature’s cannabinoid receptors, polymers will be molecularly engineered for enhanced molecular recognition of cannabinoids. These materials will be rationally designed to strongly bind cannabinoids and create changes measurable with Micro-Electro-Mechanical-Systems (MEMS) sensors, while simultaneously affording a functional handle that can be utilized to monitor gas-phase cannabinoids in real-time. The biomimetic polymers will be solution-deposited onto MEMS sensors and evaluated in a controlled environmental chamber for responsiveness to a panel of cannabinoids. Volatilized gas-phase cannabinoid concentrations will be screened, mapped against MEMS resistance and capacitance measurements, and analyzed to develop proprietary chemometric pattern recognition algorithms that uniquely identify each molecular target. The simultaneous use of chemicapacitive and chemiresistive MEMS sensors coupled with multiple molecular recognition strategies will be exploited to enhance the sensor’s molecular discriminating power, adding signal diversity across the sensor array. This approach will distinguish gas-phase cannabinoids in breath via chemometric “fingerprints” across a diversified biomimetic MEMS sensor array.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Value Proposition: Seacoast is developing the SC-Δ9, a portable, cannabis breathalyzer for point-of-use quantification of cannabinoid vapors in breath. This transformative device will offer non-invasive, analytical detection of the breath-based cannabinoid biomarkers which may be measured in the 3-hour detection window known to correlate with peak marijuana intoxication. This user-friendly breathalyzer will possess the appropriate characteristics in cost, sensitivity, selectivity, and form factor to meet the stated needs of law enforcement and employers needing accurate, portable analytical tools for cannabis sobriety enforcement. The SC-Δ9, will also possess the capacity to measure blood alcohol content and will utilize an inexpensive, disposable sensor to ensure high-performance and maximum end-user safety.

Phase I R&D: In Phase I, Seacoast and our collaborators at UT Austin successfully established proof-of-concept for a low-cost, polymer-based THC detection platform, validating the sensor's ability to monitor sorption of cannabinoid vapors by demonstrating reproducible detection of gas-phase THC at parts per billion (ppb) limits of detection (LOD) in real-time. Our R&D efforts led to the development of polymers designed for chemoselective recognition of the breath-based cannabinoid vapors that are markers of cannabis intoxication. Absorption of these vapors in the polymers triggers changes to their bulk properties that can be exploited as real-time chemical transduction signals. Moreover, the simultaneous use multiple polymer-coated sensors with orthogonal transduction signals can be leveraged to map a chemometric "fingerprint", that uniquely identifies each cannabinoid ligand at ppb-ppt LODs. 

Phase I Outcomes Report: To explore the feasibility of the polymer-based cannabinoid detection platform proposed to enable the advent of a low-cost cannabis breathalyzer, five technical hurdles were addressed in Phase I; 1) development of a cannabinoid vapor delivery and detection method, 2) synthesis of cannabinoid sensitive materials, 3) integration of these materials into low-cost chemical transducers, 4) demonstration of their sensitivity to cannabinoids and select interferents, and 5) analysis of the structure-function properties needed to systematically optimize the signal, selectivity, device integration, longevity, reusability, and cost of this innovative detection platform. 

To investigate sensitivity, a series of polymers incorporating bioinspired chemical features were prepared to support polymer-cannabinoid interactions. A separate series of polymer composites containing ligands known to bind strongly with THC were also developed in parallel. These sets of polymers were used explore the chemical parameter space of cannabinoid-sensitive features needed to develop the molecular design rules which would facilitate rational improvements in materials design to enhance cannabinoid sensitivity and selectivity. A range of solution-processable polymer formulations and composite blends were developed, optimized, and coated onto Seacoast's proprietary sensors. These sensors were then exposed to a range of vapor concentrations including toluene, acetone, methanol, H2O, isopropanol, and ethanol and analyzed for performance under conditions of variable temperature and humidity in a controlled environmental chamber. Subsequently, the sensors were exposed to an array of cannabinoid vapors to examine cannabinoid-sensitivity. The top-performing materials from Phase I were down-selected for more extensive testing and final optimization in Phase II. The success metrics outlined in the Aims of Phase I were successfully met and several of the deliverables were exceeded.

Broader Impacts: 1) A handheld cannabis breathalyzer will help ensure that law enforcement personnel have access to an accurate and reliable, field-deployable, non-invasive THC-DUI test, improving the safety of our roads. 2) A cannabis breathalyzer will serve as a deterrent to driving under the influence of cannabis. 3) A field-worthy cannabis breathalyzer will help reduce evidence backlogs at police drug labs by using the detector's results to leverage DUI plea bargains; lowering the number of court cases and saving the justice system valuable resources. 4) With an accurate, portable cannabis breathalyzer in the hands of law enforcement, the determination of cannabis impairment will be more objective, reducing the chance of innocent people being mistakenly arrested due to field sobriety tests that rely on techniques that may be susceptible to human error and/or bias. 5) Employers who forbid "working-under-the-influence" will be empowered with a real-time sobriety test, allowing responsible "off-duty" cannabis consumption to not be penalized if it does not affect job performance.
